Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Fundamentals of Wireless Networks using Metamaterial-enhanced Magnetic Induction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Existing wireless networks do not perform in many hostile and complex environments, including the underground, underwater, oil reservoirs, groundwater aquifers, nuclear plants, pipelines, tunnels, and the concrete buildings. The wireless networking capability in such environments can enable important applications in the environmental, industrial, homeland security, law enforcement, and military fields, such as monitoring and maintenance of groundwater and/or oil reservoirs using wireless sensor networks, damage assessment and mitigation in nuclear plants using robot swarms, or real-time projection of information to and from military squads in unknown tunnels and bunkers, among others. However, the harsh wireless channels prevent the direct usage of the electromagnetic (EM) wave-based techniques due to the high material absorption when penetrating the lossy medium. Moreover, since practical environments can be complex combinations of air, water, soil, concrete, and metal, solutions only applicable for one single medium, e.g., acoustic wave based networking for underwater medium, do not work. To this end, this project investigates the wireless networks based on a new communication mechanism, i.e., metamaterial-enhanced magnetic induction (M2I), which can establish reliable wireless connections in the aforementioned hostile and complex environments. The project can eliminate the environmental barriers to existing wireless applications and radically change current communication and sensing systems.

The project will explore the fundamentals of M2I-based wireless networks through a closed-loop combination of mathematical modeling, simulations, and experimental evaluation. M2I uses magnetic induction (MI) as the physical signal carrier for best penetration. Different from the very limited range in most MI techniques, M2I takes advantage of a metamaterial layer outside each antenna to achieve reasonable communication range for practical applications (tens of meters with pocket-sized devices). Moreover, all the nodes in the wireless network as well as the conductive objects in the environments are strongly coupled together (due to M2I), forming a Meta-environment, which enables unique networking functionalities, such as the passive relaying and environment-aware localization. The core contributions are in four main thrusts: (i) M2I antenna modeling and design; (ii) channel, interference, and capacity analysis under the new networking paradigm; (iii) environment-aware localization algorithms based on the M2I-enabled cognition capability; (iv) performance evaluation and prototyping through a cross layer simulator based on Comsol Multiphysics and NS-3, and a testbed based on software-defined radios and lab-fabricated metamaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes of this two-year-long effort comprise fundamental scientific contributions across fields, ranging from metamaterial-inspired devices (metamaterial-enhanced magnetic induction antennas and transceivers) to communication and signal processing techniques (channel models in complex underground and underwater environments, environment-aware networking and localization algorithms) for wireless networks of mobile and portable devices in extreme environments. More specifically, we have developed a systematic methodology for the analytical design and modeling of Metamaterial-enhanced Magnetic Induction (M2I) antennas, which will be utilized to both transmit and receive the wireless signal in extreme environments. The unique effects of metamaterials on the wireless communication are analyzed, which clearly explains the M2I mechanism in the aspects of both rigorous mathematics and intuitive physics. Second, we have for the first time designed and implemented a prototype of M2I antenna and transceiver. The developed M2I antenna is integrated with the USRP software-defined radio platform, resulting in the first M2I communication testbed. Based on the M2I testbed, we design and implement the first M2I communication physical layer module in the NI USRP N210 SDR platform, where the optimal operating frequency, modulation scheme, and transmission data rate are determined. The testbed has proved the concept of the M2I communication with excellent performance and has been used as the evaluation tool for the communication and localization techniques developed in this project. Third, we developed a rigorous analytical M2I channel model that accurately characterizes the M2I antenna properties and the M2I signal propagation in homogeneous lossy environments, such as soil and lake water. Moreover, we quantitatively analyze and model the influence of metallic objects as well as media boundaries in the surrounding environments, which complete the comprehensive M2I channel model. Using the developed channel model, we proposed an environment-aware communication mechanism to smartly utilize the positive factors and prevent the negative factors from the M2I channel, which is realized by learning the environment based on M2I feedback and selecting the optimal operating frequency and routing relays in the networks. Fourth, we have developed the M2I-based localization technique to obtain the position information of the wireless devices, which are essential to most wireless applications (e.g., navigation and sensing) and networking functionalities (e.g., position-based routing and link quality estimation). Through this two-year EAGER project, we confirm the feasibility of achieving large communication range in M2I systems by using pocket-sized wireless devices. The theory, the design guidelines, and the implementation experience lay solid foundation for the future M2I applications.
